node.title: How an ancient message shows the path to protecting Aboriginal communities from COVID-19
node.alt: The NT Health COVID-19 rapid response team assessing the locked down community of Rockhole on the outskirts of Katherine.
node.description: If the urgent problems fuelling COVID-19 outbreaks in Indigenous communities aren't addressed, things will continue to go poorly for First Nations people across Australia, writes Tynan King.
node.content:
["There is an engraving of a brush turkey on a rock shelf near Wollombi, in the NSW Hunter Valley.\u00a0", "It was made thousands of years ago by the Wonnorua people, the traditional owners of the area.\u00a0", "Elders use the site to teach people about responsibility.\u00a0They say the sections inside the turkey are like roles. Things go well for the turkey when responsibility for each role is taken. Things go poorly when they are not.\u00a0", "", "
The brush turkey engraving in Wollombi.(Supplied)
", "Last month, ABC Investigations travelled to Wilcannia to report a litany of failures that saw the small town become Australia's worst COVID-19 outbreak. It became clear that responsibility had not been taken for three critical problems.\u00a0", "Now other remote towns, this time in the Northern Territory, are struggling with their own Delta outbreaks that we weren't well prepared for.\u00a0", "If the issues these outbreaks have exposed aren't addressed, things will continue to go poorly for First Nations communities across Australia.\u00a0", "", "
NT records one new COVID-19 case, bringing cluster to 52 cases
", "
Providing appropriate housing\u00a0
", "At least 152 people \u2014\u00a0or one\u00a0third of the Indigenous population of Wilcannia \u2014\u00a0contracted COVID-19.\u00a0", "Most of the transmission occurred because of overcrowded housing. Households of 10, 15 and even 20 people provided a climate in which Delta spread quickly.\u00a0", "Similar substandard housing and chronic overcrowding exists in remote Aboriginal communities across Australia.\u00a0", "The latest census data suggests about one in five Indigenous Australians are living in a crowded home. The figure is 34 per cent in remote areas.\u00a0", "Attention is now turning to the Northern Territory, where the remote Binjari and Rockhole communities are experiencing an outbreak. There are now 52 cases of COVID-19 in the Territory and authorities say transmission is occurring because of crowded households.\u00a0", "NSW Health eventually provided Wilcannia with 30 motorhomes so close contacts could isolate safely. However, they have been heavily criticised for not providing the emergency accommodation quickly enough.", "If other remote Aboriginal communities are to avoid a situation like Wilcannia, alternative housing needs to be available before COVID-19 arrives on the\u00a0doorstep.\u00a0", "", "
Binjari is under a hard lockdown amid a local outbreak of COVID-19.(Supplied: NT Health)
", "
Addressing disparities in vaccination rates\u00a0
", "In the original vaccine rollout strategy, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were classed as one of the highest priority groups for vaccination.", "Despite this, the latest national data shows only 60 per cent of Indigenous people over the age of 16 are fully vaccinated, compared with 86 per cent of Australians overall.\u00a0", "When the NSW Delta outbreak began, the vaccination rate in the Far West Local Health District \u2014\u00a0which includes Wilcannia \u2014\u00a0was only 17 per cent.\u00a0", "That figure led local MP Roy Butler to call for a targeted communication program that spruiked the benefits of vaccination.\u00a0", "", "
The state elected Member for Barwon, Roy Butler.(ABC News)
", "Butler thought misinformation on social media was fuelling vaccine hesitancy in Indigenous communities. When he raised the issue with the NSW Government, he was emailed links to the government's latest health advice and NSW Health Aboriginal health resources.\u00a0", "Butler believes there was little acknowledgement that low literacy rates and connectivity issues exist in his Barwon electorate.\u00a0", "The Far West Local Health District's vaccination rate is now up at 92.8 per cent \u2014 and NSW Health the LHD should be commended for their work there\u00a0\u2014\u00a0but rates in some other remote communities have fallen behind the national average.\u00a0", "A culturally appropriate communication plan that explains the benefits of vaccination will go a long way to boosting rates and safeguarding these communities. Such a plan should feature prominent Indigenous Australians, Aboriginal designed graphics, language that considers the varying literacy levels in remote areas and, importantly, it must be easily available and shareable.\u00a0", "
Involving Aboriginal people in decision making processes
", "Wollombi \u2014 the town close to the turkey engraving\u00a0\u2014\u00a0is an Aboriginal word that means \"meeting place\".\u00a0", "Historically, Aboriginal people travelled there from across NSW to discuss their cultural responsibilities.", "", "
Aunty Monica Kerwin has raised issues with the state government about its handling of the pandemic in Wilcannia.(ABC News: Dave Maguire)
", "The mechanism the NSW Government uses to discuss its response to COVID-19 is the Local Emergency Management Committee (LEMC). Aboriginal people are invited to these meetings but in Wilcannia, elders felt they were being ignored and stopped attending.\u00a0", "All of Australia's health departments and Aboriginal community-controlled health organisations recommend involving Aboriginal people in decision making. As the nation reopens, our leaders must ensure Aboriginal people not only have a seat at the table and a say in decisions that affect their communities \u2014 but that they're confident their views are being listened to and acted on.\u00a0", "
A message from the past
", "The brush turkey engraving near Wollombi is around 10,000 years old.\u00a0", "Generation after generation etched its outline in the rock so that its message survived through the centuries.\u00a0", "With rates of Delta infection in the Indigenous population double that of the non-Indigenous population, it's a message our governments should heed.\u00a0", "We've known from the start that Indigenous Australians are among our most vulnerable in a pandemic, and that is coming to pass.\u00a0"]
